childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1974-1986

You were born the year Nixon resigned in disgrace, waving from the helicopter like he was headed to a vacation instead of historical infamy. Gerald Ford took over and promptly pardoned him, teaching you early that accountability was optional if you were powerful enough. The first UPC barcode was scanned on a pack of Wrigley's gum that June. Somewhere, a grocery store clerk was made redundant and didn't even know it yet.

Your earliest memories are probably coated in the amber haze of the late '70s—harvest gold appliances, wood-paneled station wagons, and the constant background hum of inflation. Your parents talked about gas prices the way people now talk about housing costs. The energy crisis meant waiting in lines. It also meant everyone's thermostat was set to 65 and you wore sweaters indoors.

You were five when the Iran hostage crisis started. Six when Reagan was shot. Seven when MTV launched and music became something you watched. Eight when E.T. made everyone cry. Ten when Ghostbusters made everyone laugh. Twelve when the Challenger exploded, and you watched your teacher's face crumble because she'd been rooting for Christa McAuliffe like everyone else.

Your childhood was analog in ways that are now extinct. Three TV channels, maybe PBS if the antenna cooperated. You called time and temperature on the phone when you were bored. The public library was the internet. If you wanted information, you looked it up in an encyclopedia or you didn't find it. Delayed gratification wasn't a virtue—it was just Tuesday.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980. That's roughly 65 million Americans sandwiched between the largest generation in history and the one that would eventually surpass it. You're the middle child of demographics, and you've acted like it—independent, skeptical, and slightly resentful of all the attention everyone else gets.

The defining characteristic of Gen X is that nobody defined you at all. You were the first latchkey generation. Your parents were at work, or divorced, or both. You let yourself in after school, made your own snacks, and figured things out. This wasn't trauma at the time. It was just childhood. In retrospect, it made you self-reliant in ways that border on pathological.

Your generation watched institutions fail in real-time. Watergate proved the president could be a criminal. Vietnam proved the government could lie about a war. The economy of the '70s proved that prosperity wasn't guaranteed. You learned early that authority figures were fallible, that systems were unreliable, and that the only person you could really count on was yourself.

Gen X never got a defining moment the way Boomers got Woodstock or Millennials got 9/11. You got a series of smaller betrayals that accumulated into a general suspicion of big promises. You're the generation that invented irony as a lifestyle. Sincerity was for suckers. Cool was not caring, or at least pretending not to.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Godfather Part II proved sequels could be art, not just cash grabs. Chinatown taught everyone that sometimes the bad guys win. Young Frankenstein made everyone laugh. People magazine launched, beginning the modern celebrity industrial complex that would eventually consume all media.

Musically, 1974 was the year ABBA won Eurovision with 'Waterloo,' beginning their campaign to make every human on Earth know the words to 'Dancing Queen.' Elton John was everywhere. Stevie Wonder released 'Innervision.' The Ramones formed in a Queens basement, planting the seeds for punk rock.

Your childhood was soundtracked by the transition from disco to new wave to MTV. You probably remember exactly where you were when you first saw the 'Thriller' video. You know all the words to songs by bands that broke up before you were ten. The music of your youth is now 'classic rock,' which is a polite way of saying your parents' music became your music.

TV in your childhood meant Happy Days, Laverne & Shirley, and The Love Boat. Saturday mornings were sacred—cereal and cartoons, no adults allowed. By the time you were a teenager, MTV had revolutionized everything. The Breakfast Club came out when you were eleven. Ferris Bueller when you were twelve. These weren't just movies. They were documentaries about your life, or at least the life you wanted.

Your generation pioneered the concept of cool as a full-time job. You wore flannel before it was grunge and after it was grunge. You had strong opinions about Nirvana versus Pearl Jam. You probably owned a leather jacket you couldn't quite pull off but wore anyway.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born the year the Altair 8800 was still a year away, when 'computer' meant a room-sized machine that only governments and universities could afford. Personal computing wasn't personal yet. It was theoretical.

Your childhood technology was mechanical and electromechanical. Rotary phones. Manual typewriters. Cameras with film you had to get developed and wait a week to see if your thumb was covering the lens. The pinnacle of home entertainment was Pong, which was two rectangles and a square but somehow mesmerizing.

You were six when the Apple II launched. Ten when the IBM PC arrived. Eleven when Time magazine made the personal computer 'Machine of the Year.' You watched computers go from curiosities to necessities in real-time. You probably learned to type on an actual typewriter before transitioning to a keyboard.

You were twenty-one when the World Wide Web became publicly available. Twenty-four when Amazon launched. Twenty-six when Google started. Thirty when Facebook opened. Thirty-three when the iPhone arrived. You didn't grow up with the internet—you watched it being built, and you were young enough to adapt completely but old enough to remember what came before.

This makes you the bridge generation for technology. You can explain email to your parents and TikTok to your kids. You remember life before screens were everywhere, which gives you perspective that younger generations lack. You know the internet is a tool, not a habitat. You use it; you don't live in it.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were four months old when Nixon resigned—the first president to do so. You don't remember it, but the cynicism it created was the water you swam in. Your parents watched a president lie on television, get caught, and walk away. The lesson was clear: the system protects its own.

You were five when Saigon fell and the Vietnam War finally ended. You were too young to understand, but the Vietnam veterans were everywhere—your uncles, your neighbors, guys at the gas station who seemed older than they were. The war shaped your parents' generation. Its aftermath shaped yours.

You were seven when Reagan was shot and barely flinched. Twelve when the Challenger exploded. You remember where you were. Everyone does. It was supposed to be inspiring—a teacher in space. Instead, it was a lesson in how quickly triumph turns to tragedy.

You were fifteen when the Berlin Wall fell. Seventeen when the Soviet Union collapsed. The Cold War was the background radiation of your entire childhood—duck and cover drills, Red Dawn, nuclear anxiety. Then it just... ended. The threat that defined your parents' entire lives evaporated, and the world had to figure out what to worry about next.

You were twenty-seven during 9/11. Old enough to have a career, a mortgage maybe, possibly kids. Old enough to understand that the world had fundamentally changed, that the post-Cold War peace dividend was over, that a new era of anxiety had begun. You've now spent more of your adult life in the post-9/11 world than you spent in the world before it.

You were thirty-four during the 2008 financial crisis. Established enough to have something to lose, young enough to have decades of recovery ahead. You watched your 401(k) crater. You watched friends lose houses. You watched the banks get bailed out while everyone else got austerity. The lesson was the same one Watergate taught: the system protects its own.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the early-to-mid '90s, which was perfect timing. The economy was growing. Jobs were available. You could actually negotiate salary because employers needed workers. The concept of loyalty to a company still meant something, even if it was already starting to fray.

You're the generation that watched the social contract between employers and employees get shredded. You started your career when pensions still existed, when people expected to work at one company for decades. You'll end it in the gig economy, with a 401(k) that may or may not be enough, dependent on the stock market's mood.

You rode the dot-com boom in your twenties. Some of you made money. Some of you lost it. All of you learned that 'disruption' usually meant someone was about to get disrupted out of a job. The bust in 2000 was a preview of 2008, which was a preview of everything since. The lesson: markets go up until they don't.

Your management style was shaped by terrible managers. You probably had a boss who took credit for your work, another who micromanaged everything, another who was promoted for being loud rather than competent. You learned what not to do, which is a form of education even if it's a painful one.

You're now in leadership positions, and you're stuck between generations who want very different things. Boomers above you still value face time and hierarchy. Millennials and Gen Z below you want flexibility and purpose. You're the translator, explaining each generation to the other while trying to get actual work done.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the last generation to date without the internet. You met people at bars, through friends, at work—in person, with no profile to pre-screen. You asked for phone numbers on napkins. You called people on landlines and talked to their roommates first. The stakes felt higher because there was no algorithm promising infinite other options.

You probably got married younger than Millennials but older than Boomers. The average age at first marriage for your cohort was mid-to-late twenties. Divorce rates peaked just before you hit marrying age, which made you cautious. You'd seen what happened when marriages failed. You'd lived it, probably.

Your generation normalized couples therapy before it was mainstream. You read relationship books, did the work, tried to communicate. The self-help industry of the '90s was built for you—Men Are from Mars, The 7 Habits, everything Oprah recommended. You were the first generation to treat relationships as projects that required effort and maintenance.

Communication evolved dramatically during your adult life. You went from landlines to cell phones to smartphones. From letters to email to text to DMs. You remember when 'I'll call you' meant something. Now it means nothing. You've adapted to every new platform, but part of you still thinks a phone call is more personal than a text.

Your friendships survived the transition from analog to digital. You have group chats with people you've known for thirty years. You've maintained connections across moves, careers, marriages, divorces. Gen X friendship is low-maintenance by design—you can go months without talking and pick up exactly where you left off.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You grew up during stagflation—high inflation, high unemployment, low growth. Your parents talked about money constantly because there never seemed to be enough. Gas lines. Layoffs. The malaise, as Carter called it. You learned early that economic security wasn't guaranteed.

You entered the workforce at the right time. The '90s economy was strong. You could save money, buy a house, build a 401(k). If you played it right, you accumulated assets when they were still affordable. This wasn't virtue—it was timing. You happened to be the right age at the right moment.

The 2008 crisis hit you mid-career. You had something to lose, and many of you lost it. Houses underwater. Retirement accounts halved. The recovery was slow and uneven. If you kept your job, you were lucky. If you lost it, you learned that 'experience' meant 'too expensive to hire.'

Your relationship with money is practical to the point of paranoia. You save because you've seen how fast things can collapse. You're skeptical of get-rich-quick schemes because you watched the dot-com bubble and the housing bubble and the crypto bubble. Bubbles always pop. The question is whether you're holding the bag.

You're the generation that will inherit from Boomers—the largest intergenerational wealth transfer in history. Some of you will receive significant inheritances. Many won't. The gap between rich Gen Xers and struggling Gen Xers will widen. Your generation's story isn't one story. It's two: those who made it and those who didn't.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is the same as your biggest strength: independence that curdles into isolation. You're so used to figuring things out alone that you don't ask for help when you need it. You don't burden others. You handle it yourself. This is admirable until it's not—until you're drowning and too proud to say so.

You've perfected the art of not caring, or pretending not to. Ironic detachment was your survival mechanism. The problem is that detachment makes it hard to engage. You can critique everything and commit to nothing. You're so busy being too cool to try that you miss opportunities for genuine connection.

Your generation is invisible in ways that hurt. You're not large enough to dominate like Boomers. You're not young enough to represent the future like Millennials and Gen Z. Policy debates happen around you, not about you. You've adapted to being overlooked, but adaptation isn't the same as acceptance.

You're cynical about institutions in ways that can be self-defeating. Voting seems pointless, so you don't vote, which makes it actually pointless. Organizing seems futile, so you don't organize, which makes change less likely. Your skepticism is earned, but it's also a cage. Sometimes the only way out is through.

You've normalized overwork as identity. You're the generation that invented 'work hard, play hard,' which really meant 'work hard, then work more.' Hustle culture was your prototype before Millennials named it. You don't know how to rest without guilt. Relaxation feels like failure.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1994-2004): The economy was good. You got jobs. You probably changed jobs a few times, because loyalty was already dying even if nobody admitted it yet. You watched the internet go from novelty to necessity. You might have gotten rich in the dot-com boom. You definitely watched someone else get rich. Your twenties were the last decade of analog adulthood, and you didn't even know it.

Your 30s (2004-2014): You hit your stride and then the floor collapsed. The 2008 crisis was a gut punch. You had mortgages, kids, responsibilities. The recovery was slower than promised. You learned that the economy could betray you at any age. You also learned resilience, because what choice did you have?

Your 40s (2014-2024): This is where you are now, or just finishing. Peak earning years, peak responsibility years. Kids are teenagers or young adults. Parents are aging. You're sandwiched between generations who need you, managing everyone else's crises while your own needs get queued. You have authority at work but wonder if the young people take you seriously. You have perspective but wonder if anyone wants it.

Your 50s (2024-2034): The next decade. Kids will be launched, or launching. Parents may be gone or going. You'll have more time and less energy, which is the cruelest trade life offers. Retirement will start feeling real instead of theoretical. You'll calculate whether you have enough. The answer will probably be 'maybe, if nothing goes wrong.' Something always goes wrong.

Your 60s and beyond (2034+): Retirement, if you can afford it. Social Security will probably exist but pay less. Medicare will probably exist but cover less. You'll be healthy until you're not, active until you're not. The world will be unrecognizable—climate changed, technology advanced, demographics shifted. You'll tell younger people about the before times. They'll think you're exaggerating.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.2 million people born in 1974. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US—smaller than Boomers before you, smaller than Millennials after. You're the demographic valley between two peaks, which explains why no one markets to you.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're more skeptical and less idealistic. Boomers believed they could change the world. You believed the world would change regardless, and probably not for the better. Boomers got cheap houses, pensions, and job security. You got the transition period, when all those things were disappearing but hadn't quite vanished.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you had it easier economically but harder emotionally. You could still buy houses when they were affordable. You could still get jobs that paid enough. But you also had less support. Nobody worried about your self-esteem. Nobody gave you participation trophies. You were expected to figure it out, and you did.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically ancient. They've never known a world without smartphones. You remember rotary phones. They've never known economic stability. You remember when jobs came with benefits. You bridge the analog and digital worlds in ways they can't understand because they only know one side.

Your life expectancy is 76-78 years, slightly lower than Boomers due to the usual culprits—stress, lifestyle, healthcare costs. You'll work longer than your parents did, retire later if you retire at all. The traditional life script—career, marriage, house, kids, retirement—was available to you in ways it wasn't for later generations, but it was already fraying at the edges.

You're the forgotten generation, which suits you fine. You never wanted the attention anyway. You'd rather be underestimated and effective than celebrated and scrutinized. That's the Gen X way: get it done, don't make a big deal about it, and definitely don't expect anyone to notice.

year_events: Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruth's home run record
